{{Feminism sidebar}}'''Feminist poetry''' is inspired by, promotes, or elaborates on feminist principles and ideas.{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/collections/146073/poetry-and-feminism|title=Poetry and Feminism|last=Golden|first=Shyama|date=|website=Poetry Foundation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=September 4, 2018}} It might be written with the conscious aim of expressing feminist principles, although sometimes it is identified as feminist by critics in a later era. Some writers are thought to express feminist ideas even if the writer was not an active member of the political movement during their era. Many feminist movements, however, have embraced poetry as a vehicle for communicating with public audiences through anthologies, poetry collections, and public readings. Formally, feminist poetry often seeks to challenge assumptions about language and meaning. It usually foregrounds women's experiences as valid and worthy of attention, and it also highlights the lived experiences of minorities and other less privileged subjects. Sometimes feminist poems seek to embody specific women's experiences, and they are often [[Intersectionality|intersectional]] registering specific forms of oppression depending on identities related to race, sexuality, gender presentation, disability, or immigration status. This has led to feminist writing journals like [http://sotospeakjournal.org/about-so-to-speak/ So To Speak] providing a statement of intention to publish the work of women and [[Genderqueer|nonbinary]] people in particular. Kim Whitehead states that feminist poetry has "no identifiable birth date," but there are a few key figures identified as early proponents of feminist ideas, and who convey their politics through poetry.{{Cite book|title=The Feminist Poetry Movement|last=Whitehead|first=Kim|publisher=University Press of Mississippi|year=1996|isbn=|location=Jackson MI|pages=3, ix-x, xii, xv, xvi, xviii, xviii-ix}} The title of first feminist poet is often given to [[Sappho]], at least in part because she seems to write about female [[homosexuality]] in [[Ancient Greece]], a culture and time when [[lesbian]] sexuality was usually ignored or erased.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/43477494|title=Reading Sappho : contemporary approaches|date=1996|publisher=University of California Press|others=Greene, Ellen, 1950-|isbn=9780520918061|location=Berkeley|oclc=43477494}}{{Cite journal|last=Jannerson|first=Deb|date=2011|title='ADVENTURES IN FEMINISTORY: SAPPHO'|url=https://www.bitchmedia.org/post/adventures-in-feministory-sappho|journal=Bitch Media|volume=|pages=|via=}}{{Cite journal|last=Catalano|first=Gabby|date=|title=How This Historic Icon Influenced Feminist Writers Today|url=http://www.womensmediacenter.com/fbomb/how-this-historic-icon-influenced-feminist-writers-today|journal=Women's Media Centre|volume=|pages=|via=}} ==Feminist Poetry in Asia== [[File:Toru Dutt.jpg|thumb|Toru Dutt]] === Feminist Aspects of Sanskrit Writing === The beginning of works categorised as literature in India began with the [[Sanskrit]] term ''[[kāvya]]'', a discourse separate from science or from the purely oral, and specific literary style that included works thought to contain a kind of soulfulness.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/70701869|title=The language of the gods in the world of men : Sanskrit, culture, and power in premodern India|last=Pollock|first=Sheldon I.|date=2006|publisher=University of California Press|year=|isbn=9780520932029|location=Berkeley|pages=3, 16, 19, 126|oclc=70701869}} In this early period, men were often posed as poets, and women as a kind of muse, as in the tenth century explanation for the origins of Indian literary culture: Poem Man's wife ("Poetics") chases him across [[South Asia]] creating varying kinds of literature across the region. Poetry was certainly an important part of political cultural life in the [[Sanskrit]] cosmopolis, and some women contributed; for example the poet [[Rajashekhara|Rajasekhara]] tells of women in different regions who entertain with songs. The early civilisation of [[Khmer Empire|Khmer]] country in modern-day Cambodia cultivated a literature in [[Sanskrit]], and diverged from its neighbours in creating a strain of poetry from the fifth century to the thirteenth century in which women were a source of praise and admiration. Take for example the Mebon Inscription of [[Rajendravarman II|Rājendravarman]], which features eulogies for specific women of note, and which is, according to Sheldon I. Pollock, "without obvious parallel in South Asia," and may be related to "specific kinship structures in the region." === Nineteenth Century Feminist Poets in India === Early anglophone women poets in India blended native traditions and literary models from Europe.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/739722886|title=Anglophone poetry in colonial India, 1780-1913 : a critical anthology|last=|first=|date=2011|publisher=Ohio University Press|others=Gibson, Mary Ellis, 1952-|year=|isbn=9780821443576|location=Athens|pages=287–288, 294–297, 363–371|oclc=739722886}} Amongst these early feminists, the Dutt Sisters - [[Toru Dutt]] (1856-1877) and Aru Dutt (1854-1874) stand out, and are sometimes compared to the [[Brontë family|Brontë Sisters]] in England. The Dutt sisters came from a family of poets, including their father Govind Chandra Dutt, and their access to education was unprecedented. The mother of the family Kshetramoni Mitter Dutt along with all three children - Toru, Aru, and their brother Abju Dutt, had received an education in English, and to some extent, in the [[Bengali language|Bengali]] language. The family had a reformist bent, and some members had converted to Christianity. Both sisters visited England in the 1870s, and attended the higher lectures for women at [[University of Cambridge|Cambridge University]]. Toru Dutt's poetry in particular has been labelled extraordinary, because her writing "created a new idiom in Indian English verse." Spanning the turn from the nineteenth to twentieth century, [[Sarojini Naidu]] (1879–1949) represents a figure for whom politics and poetry are intertwined. Like the Dutt Sisters, Naidu was allowed access to all the educational resources she desired, and she passed the [[University of Madras|Madras University]] matriculation examination at age 12. She came from a large and free-thinking family. Her father, [[Aghorenath Chattopadhyay]], was a well-regarded doctor, known for his educational reforms, and her mother, Barada Sundari Devi, was educated at a [[Brahmo]] school. Naidu had seven siblings all of whom made contribution to Indian life, for example her brother [[Virendranath Chattopadhyaya|Virendranath Chattopadhyay]] was an Indian revolutionary. Naidu studied at [[Girton College, Cambridge|Girton College]], Cambridge, which brough her into contact with writers of the day, including [[Arthur Symons]], and [[W. B. Yeats|W.B. Yeats]]. Ultimately, Naidu's unconventional upbringing and education were catalysts for her intellectual powers, since as she writes in her roman-de-clef 'Sulani,' ""Unlike the girls of her own nation, she had been brought up in an atmosphere of large un-convention and culture and absolute freedom of thought and action."{{Cite book|title="Sunalini," ms.|last=Naidu|first=Sarojini|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=British Library.|pages=EUr.A.95}} After her marriage to Govindarajulu Naidu - controversial because of his age and class - Naidu began publishing poetry to international acclaim, and in parallel with this literary art, she maintained her nationalist efforts, eventually becoming the first Indian woman to serve as president of the [[Indian National Congress]]. === Post 1960s Feminist Poetry === Anthologies were an important part of foregrounding women's writing in volumes like [[Eunice de Souza|Eunice De Souza]]'s ''Nine Indian Women Poets'' (1997).{{Cite journal|last=Bethala|first=Melody|date=February 2017|title='The battle is to validate the material': A brief history of Eunice de Souza's anthologies of Indian literature.|url=https://humag.co/features/the-battle-is-to-validate-the-material|journal=Honest Ulsterman|volume=|pages=|via=}} == Feminist Poetry in Central America and the Caribbean == [[File:Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz.JPG|thumb|Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz]] '''The Feminist Legacy of Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz''' During the Latin American colonial period, Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz (est 1651-1695) was a poet, dramatist, and nun.{{Cite web|url=https://www.poets.org/poetsorg/poet/sor-juana-in%C3%A9s-de-la-cruz|title=Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz|last=Cruz|first=Sor Juana Inés de la|date=2003-02-04|website=Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz|language=en|access-date=2018-09-19}} Exceptionally talented and intelligent, Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz chose to spend most of her life in the Convent of the Order of St. Jérôme, and her response to a critical Bishop, ''Respuesta a Sor Filotea,'' is hailed as one of the first feminist manifestos. Not only did Sor Juana have to deal with the criticisms of men of her era, but she also faced the Spanish perception of literature from the colonies as second-rate.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/985840432|title=Routledge research companion to the works of Sor Juana Inés de la Cruz|last=Schlau|first=edited by Emilie L. Bergmann and Stacey|publisher=|year=|isbn=9781317041641|location=London|pages=xi|oclc=985840432}} Sor Juana's poems challenge the assumptions of men about women, for example in [https://www.poets.org/poetsorg/poem/you-foolish-men 'You Foolish Men.']
What kind of mind is odder than his who mists a mirror and then complains that it's not clear.{{Cite web|url=https://www.poets.org/poetsorg/poem/you-foolish-men|title=You Foolish Men|last=aapone|date=2010-06-07|website=You Foolish Men|language=en|access-date=2018-09-19}}
The fact that she chooses to avoid a heteronormative life with marriage and children is often held up as a feminist choice, and she represents the possibility to be a woman who 'pursues knowledge and procreates only through art and not through a genetic legacy.'{{Cite book|url=https://www.palgrave.com/us/book/9780230104464|title=Femmenism and the Mexican Woman Intellectual from Sor Juana to Poniatowska - Boob Lit {{!}} Emily Hind {{!}} Palgrave Macmillan|last=|first=|publisher=|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=34|language=en}} === Post 1960s Feminist Poetry in Central America and the Caribbean === Anthologies of women's writing in the 1980s foregrounded the importance of women poets in the Caribbean, for example in M.J. Fenwick's ''Sisters of Caliban'' (1996) described as "a gendered and racialized position of resistance".{{Cite journal|last=Lara|first=Irene|date=2007|title=Beyond Caliban's Curses: The Decolonial Feminist Literacy of Sycorax|url=https://vc.bridgew.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?referer=https://www.google.com/&httpsredir=1&article=1289&context=jiws|journal=Journal of International Women's Studies|volume=9.1|pages=97|via=}} ==Feminist Poetry in North America == [[File:Joy harjo 3271646.JPG|thumb|Poet Joy Harjo's argument for the centrality and importance of native poetry in North America is significant for feminist literary histories.]] === Early Feminist Poets in North America === Though they lived in an era before an organised feminist movement, certain American poets have been lauded by [[feminist literary criticism]] as early examples of feminist writers. Feminist poetry in the United States is often thought of as beginning with [[Anne Bradstreet]] (1612-1672), the first poet of the [[New World]]. There were also, however, native poetic traditions before colonialism, which continue to the present day, and represent an important strand of American poetry. [[Native Americans in the United States|Native]] traditional verse has included "lyrics, chants, anecdotes, incantations, riddles, proverbs, and legends."{{Cite book|title=A Preface to Colonial American Poetry: A Study in the Poetry of the Age in Relation to American History and Literature|last=Jabbar|first=Wisam Abdul|publisher=iUniverse|year=2005|isbn=|location=|pages=57}} While it is difficult to ascertain from these oral traditions whether the authors of early texts were male or female, precolonial native poetry certainly addresses issues relevant to women in a sensitive and positive way, for example the [[Seminole]] poem, 'Song for Bringing a Child Into the World.'{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/865473325|title=Native American songs and poems : an anthology|last=|first=|publisher=|others=Swann, Brian,|year=|isbn=9780486112138|location=Mineola, New York|pages=1|oclc=865473325}} In fact, native poetry is a separate but relevant tradition in the United States; as poet [[Joy Harjo]] comments, "The literature of the aboriginal people of North America defines America. It is not exotic."{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/collections/144560/native-american-poetry-and-culture|title=Native American Poetry and Culture|last=|first=|date=|website=Poetry Foundation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018}} In the context of Canada, Anne Marie Dalton argues that at least some indigenous communities in North America (though not all) have lived by practicing [[ecofeminism]] with regard to women's roles, and the sustainability of the land.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/671640200|title=The Cambridge history of Canadian literature|last=|first=|date=2009|publisher=Cambridge University Press|others=Howells, Coral Ann., Kröller, Eva-Marie.|year=|isbn=9780511862243|location=Cambridge|pages=78–80|oclc=671640200}} When colonialism did arrive, Anne Bradstreet was one of the first poets to win acclaim, and many of her poems are thought to have feminist themes. The mother of eight children, Bradstreet sometimes found herself in conflict with her domestic circumstances and her role as a [[Puritans|Puritan]] woman.{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/anne-bradstreet|title=Anne Bradstreet|last=Martin|first=Wendy|date=|website=Poetry Foundation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Feminist literary criticism defined Bradstreet in retrospect as a "protofeminist," because of her "gender awareness," and her treatment of domestic concerns of importance in women's lives.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/785576747|title=Feminist writings from ancient times to the modern world : a global sourcebook and history|last=|first=|date=2011|publisher=Greenwood|others=Wayne, Tiffany K., 1968-|year=|isbn=9780313345814|location=Santa Barbara|pages=106|oclc=785576747}} Poet [[Alicia Ostriker]] describes Bradstreet's style as "a combination of rebellion and submission," a pattern that Ostriker also sees in poets to come like [[Phillis Wheatley|Phyllis Wheatley]] and [[Emily Dickinson]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/podcasts/92110/a-change-of-world-episode-1-the-wilderness|title=A Change of World, Episode 1: The Wilderness|last=Fox|first=Curtis|date=2018|website=Poetry Foundation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} [[Phillis Wheatley|Phyllis Wheatley]] (1753-1784) was brought to the United States from Africa as a slave, and sold to the Wheatley family of Boston in 1771.{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/phillis-wheatley|title=Phillis Wheatley|last=O'Neale|first=Sondra A.|date=|website=Poetry Foundation.|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} A prodigy as a child, Wheatley was the first black person to publish a book of poems in the American colony, and though her poems are sometimes thought of as expressing "meek submission," she is also what [[Camille Dungy]] describes as "a foremother," and a role model for black women poets as "part of the fabric" of American poetry. Involved in the abolitionist movement, Wheatley became "a spokeswoman for the cause of [[American independence]] and the [[Abolitionism|abolition of slavery]]."{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/316827798|title=The right to write : the literary politics of Anne Bradstreet and Phillis Wheatley|last=Seidler.|first=Engberg, Kathrynn|date=2010|publisher=University Press of America|year=|isbn=9780761846093|location=Lanham, MD|pages=xvi|oclc=316827798}} Nineteenth century poet [[Emily Dickinson]] (1830-1886) is often thought of as feminist, though she never wrote for public audiences. Not necessarily recognized in her own lifetime, Dickinson offers powerful female speakers. Engaging with male writers like [[Ralph Waldo Emerson]] or [[William Wordsworth]], her work is praised for developing "others ways of representing the position of a female speaking subject" in particular romantic and psychological dynamics.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/22490475|title=Dickinson and the boundaries of feminist theory|last=1958-|first=Loeffelholz, Mary,|date=1991|publisher=University of Illinois Press|year=|isbn=0252017897|location=Urbana|pages=22–25|oclc=22490475}} See for example the declaration of desire and longing in [https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems/44087/wild-nights-wild-nights-269 'Wild nights - Wild nights!.'] In the 1970s, [[feminist literary criticism]] articulated Dickinson's feminism through groundbreaking studies by [[Margaret Homans]], [[Sandra Gilbert]] and [[Susan Gubar]], and Suzanne Juhasz. Critics point in particular to Dickinson's expression of anger at women's confinement, to her re-gendering of external and internal realities, to her use of feminist motifs, and to her articulation of her particular position in Puritan, patriarchal culture.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/185033031|title=Approaching Emily Dickinson : critical currents and crosscurrents since 1960|last=1943-|first=White, Fred D.,|date=2008|publisher=Camden House|year=|isbn=9781571133168|location=Rochester, N.Y.|pages=65–70|oclc=185033031}} Dickinson also proves that confinement to domestic life does not dictate an inability to create great poetry. As the poet [[Adrienne Rich]] writes, "Probably no poet ever lived so much and so purposefully in one house; even, in one room."{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/4195229|title=Shakespeare's sisters : feminist essays on women poets|last=|first=|date=1979|publisher=Indiana University Press|others=Gilbert, Sandra M., Gubar, Susan, 1944-|year=|isbn=0253112583|location=Bloomington|pages=99|oclc=4195229}} ===Post 1900s North American Feminist Poets=== [[File:Alice Dunbar Nelson cropped.jpg|thumb|Alice Moore Dunbar-Nelson]] Feminist poets of the early twentieth century harnessed the new opportunities and rights which came as a result of coeducational resources now afforded to women.{{Cite book|url=http://www.worldcat.org/oclc/928779869|title=A history of twentieth-century American women's poetry|last=Kinnhan.|first=Linda|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=2016|isbn=|location=Cambridge|pages=|oclc=}} Cristianne Miller goes so far as to say that 'In no period before and rarely since have women poets had greater success and influence than in the first half of the twentieth century in the United States.' Living through the turn of the century was [[Alice Dunbar Nelson|Alice Moore Dunbar-Nelson]](1875-1935), a poet often thought of in relation to her marriage to [[Paul Laurence Dunbar|Paul Dunbar]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/alice-moore-dunbar-nelson|title=Alice Moore Dunbar-Nelson|last=|first=|date=|website=Poetry Foundation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Dunbar-Nelson, however, is an accomplished writer in her own right, praised by poet [[Camille Dungy]] for breaking out of writing only about "black women's things," instead addressing "the theater and war of life." Born in New Orleans, Dubar-Nelson's family had a heritage of African American, Anglo, Native American, and Creole roots. [[Camille Dungy]] suggests that bringing black women writers like Dunbar-Nelson into the feminist canon alongside Bradstreet and Dickinson is of great importance in rediscovering literary foremothers for black women writers. The early twentieth century was also a significant moment for feminism, because it saw the rise of the [[Women's suffrage|suffragist]] movement, and poets responded to the political moment by writing poems regarding the debate as to whether or not women should have the right to vote. In her collection ''Suffrage Songs and Verses,'' [[Charlotte Perkins Gilman]] criticises wealthy women, who because they live a life of ease, deny other women their rights.{{Cite web|url=http://digital.library.upenn.edu/women/gilman/suffrage/suffrage.html#anti|title=Suffrage Songs and Verses.|website=digital.library.upenn.edu|access-date=2018-09-17}} [[Alice Duer Miller]] (1874-1942) wrote poems mocking [[Anti-suffragism|anti-suffragist]] advocates, which were published in the [[New-York Tribune|New York Tribune]], a popular news outlet of the era.{{Cite web|url=http://www.aliceduermiller.com|title=Alice Duer Miller|website=www.aliceduermiller.com|access-date=2018-09-17}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/harriet/2012/01/are-women-people-the-suffragist-poems-of-alice-duer-miller|title=Are Women People? The suffragist poems of Alice Duer Miller by Harriet Staff|date=2018-09-17|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-17}}{{Cite news|url=https://www.thehairpin.com/2012/01/are-women-people/|title=Are Women People?|date=2012-01-19|work=The Hairpin|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en-US}} While some poets have been embraced by the feminist canon, others are seen as awkward additions in spite of their success, for example [[Gertrude Stein]] (1874-1946) is often defined more as a poet involved in modernist experimentation than feminist discourse.{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/gertrude-stein|title=Gertrude Stein|date=2018-09-17|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-17}} Some of modernism's tenets seem incompatible with some kinds of feminism, like the repression of emotion, and avoidance of domesticity. Nevertheless, second wave feminists found modernist women poets like [[H.D.]] (1886-1961) to be a powerful example, unfairly overlooked by male critics.{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/h-d|title=H. D.|date=2018-09-17|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-17}} By the time of the 1940s, magazines were being set up which, though perhaps not obviously feminist, certainly in their practices were very different to male-run publications: take for example [[Contemporary Verse 2|Contemporary Verse]] (1941–52) published in Canada by a group of women writers, including [[Dorothy Livesay]], [[P. K. Page|P.K. Page]], and [[Anne Marriott]].{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/969538355|title=The making of modern poetry in Canada : essential commentary on Canadian poetry in English|last=|first=|publisher=|others=Gnarowski, Michael, 1934-, Dudek, Louis, 1918-2001,|year=|isbn=9780773549609|edition= Third|location=Montreal|pages=xxix, xxv|oclc=969538355}} ===Post 1960 North American Feminist Poets=== [[File:Audre Lorde.jpg|thumb|Audre Lorde]] Historian [[Ruth Rosen]] describes the mainstream poetry world before 1960 as "an all boy's club," adding that poetry was not "women's place," and explains that in order to get a poetry book published, writers would have to overcome their gender and race.{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/podcasts/101723/books-that-broke-down-barriers|title="A Change of World, Episode 2: Books that Broke Down Barriers"|last=Fox|first=Curtis|date=|website=Poetry Foundation.|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} The interest of American feminist poets in the rights of minorities have often put them in conflict with American institutions like the [[Academy of American Poets|American Academy of Poets]]. One of the strategies of feminist poets is to demonstrate "their opposition to a dominant poetry culture that does not recognize the primacy of gender and other oppressions". [[1960s]] feminist poetry provided a useful space for [[Second-wave feminism|second wave]] American feminist politics.{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/collections/146073/poetry-and-feminism|title=Poetry and Feminism|last=|first=|date=|website=Poetry Foundation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} The poets, however, were not necessarily unified in their themes or formal techniques, but had links to specific movements and trends, such as the New York Poets, the [[Black Mountain poets]], the [[San Francisco Renaissance]], or the [[Beat poets|Beat Poets]]. [[Denise Levertov]] (1923-1997), for example, refined and built upon poetics from the [[Black Mountain poets|Black Mountain]] School.{{Cite journal|last=Levertov|first=Denise|date=1965|title=Some Notes on Organic Form|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/articles/69392/some-notes-on-organic-form-56d249032078f|journal=Poetry|volume=|pages=|via=}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/denise-levertov|title=Denise Levertov|date=2018-09-17|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-17}} Women like [[Sylvia Plath]] (1932-1963) and [[Anne Sexton]] (1928-1974) provided a feminist version of the [[Confessional poetry|Confessional Poets]]' poetics, which worked alongside feminist texts of the day, like [[Betty Friedan]]'s ''[[The Feminine Mystique]]'', to "address taboo subjects and social limitations that plagued American women" (although Plath died before ''The Feminine Mystique'' was published){{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/harriet/2014/09/confessionalism-feminism-at-coldfront|title=Confessionalism and Feminism at Coldfront|last=Harriet|first=Staff|date=|website=Poetry Foundation|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/anne-sexton|title=Anne Sexton|date=2018-09-17|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-17}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/sylvia-plath|title=Sylvia Plath|date=2018-09-17|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-17}} [[Lucille Clifton]] (1936-2010) also borrowed from [[Confessional poetry|Confessional]] poetics, a strategy that was key according to [[Adrienne Rich]] for avoiding being trapped between "misogynist black male critics and white feminists still struggling to unearth a white woman's tradition."{{Cite web|url=http://coldfrontmag.com/confessionalism-birthed-from-feminism-jd/|title=Confessionalism Birthed from Feminism|last=Wilson|first=Merida|date=|website=http://coldfrontmag.com/confessionalism-birthed-from-feminism-jd/|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/lucille-clifton|title=Lucille Clifton|date=2018-09-17|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-17}} [[Confessional poetry|Confessionalism]] lent to feminist poetry the possibility of agency for the female speaker, and the refusal to present well-behaved women, though it was troubling that the Confessional women poets who committed suicide tended to be foregrounded and promoted in poetry circles. [[Muriel Rukeyser]] (1913-1980) was a generation older than Plath and Sexton, and rejected the suicidal poetics of the Confessional writers. Rukeyser also wrote frankly about the body and sexuality, inspiring later poets like [[Sharon Olds]].{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/podcasts/144891/a-change-of-world-episode-4-a-place-of-permission|title=A Change of World, Episode 4 : A Place of Permission - Poetry Off the Shelf|date=2018-09-26|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-26}} In addition, Rukeyser's leftist politics and militant writing style proved to be a model for poet [[Adrienne Rich]]. Both poets also contributed to the [[Anti-Vietnam War Movement|anti-Vietnam War movement]]: for example [[Muriel Rukeyser|Rukeyser]] and [[Adrienne Rich|Rich]] took part in readings as part of the event series, the Week of the Angry Arts Against the War in Vietnam. [[Adrienne Rich]] (1929-2012) also became a key feminist poet, praised by [[Alicia Ostriker]] for bringing "intellect" to poetry, "something that women were not supposed to have," as well as "a leftward leaning sensibility in which coming out as lesbian was just one part."{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/adrienne-rich|title=Adrienne Rich|date=2018-09-17|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-17}} Rich's [https://www.poets.org/poetsorg/poem/diving-wreck 'Diving into the Wreck'] is an important feminist poem, as it describes moving down as an act of triumph, where the wreck might be history, literature, or human life, and the poem itself is a kind of "battlecry." Famously, when Rich received the National Book Award for her collection, ''Diving into the Wreck,'' she accepted it on behalf of all the female nominees, including [[Audre Lorde]] and [[Alice Walker]]:
We, Audre Lorde, Adrienne Rich, and Alice Walker, together accept this award in the name of all the women whose voices have gone and still go unheard in a patriarchal world, and in the name of those who, like us, have been tolerated as token women in this culture, often at great cost and in great pain. We believe that we can enrich ourselves more in supporting and giving to each other than by competing against each other; and that poetry— if it is poetry— exists in a realm beyond ranking and comparison. We symbolically join together here in refusing the terms of patriarchal competition and declaring that we will share this prize among us, to be used as best we can for women.{{Cite web|url=http://www.nationalbook.org/nbaacceptspeech_arich_74.html#.W5_7ri-ZN8c|title=National Book Awards Acceptance Speeches: ADRIENNE RICH, WINNER OF THE 1974 NATIONAL BOOK AWARD FOR DIVING INTO THE WRECK|last=Rich|first=Adrienne|date=1974|website=National Book Foundation.|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=2018}}
[[Audre Lorde]] (1934-1992) was a feminist poet whose poetry and prose writings have had a great impact on feminist thinking to the present day.{{Cite web|url=https://www.newstatesman.com/culture/books/2017/09/feminist-lesbian-warrior-poet-rediscovering-work-audre-lorde|title=Feminist, lesbian, warrior, poet: rediscovering the work of Audre Lorde|website=www.newstatesman.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-17}}{{Cite web|url=https://frieze.com/article/what-audre-lordes-language-self-care-can-teach-us-after-metoo|title=What Audre Lorde's Language of Self-Care Can Teach Us After #MeToo|website=frieze.com|language=en|access-date=2018-09-17}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/audre-lorde|title=Audre Lorde|date=2018-09-17|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-17}} Sometimes thought of as a writer who developed a "black lesbian eroticism," Lorde's poetry also shows a deep ethical and moral commitment, which seeks to challenge racism, sexism, and homophobia.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/53315369|title=Warrior poet : a biography of Audre Lorde|last=1948-|first=De Veaux, Alexis,|date=2004|publisher=W.W. Norton|year=|isbn=0393019543|edition= 1st|location=New York|pages=4|oclc=53315369}} Many of Lorde's poems have a great deal in common with the modern-day campaign [[Black Lives Matter|#blacklivesmatter]], as they pose questions about institutionalised racism in American public services like the price force, for example in her poem [https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems/53918/power-56d233adafeb3 'Power']:
A policeman who shot down a ten year old in Queens stood over the boy with his cop shoes in childish blood and a voice said "Die you little motherfucker" and there are tapes to prove it. At his trial this policeman said in his own defense "I didn't notice the size nor nothing else only the color". And there are tapes to prove that, too.{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems/53918/power-56d233adafeb3|title=Power by Audre Lorde|date=2018-09-17|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-17}}
Lorde's work has also proved to be an inspiration to feminists working on the subject of feminist [[wikt:killjoy|killjoy]]s, and the trope of the angry black woman, often used as an excuse to belittle or reduce the impact of just concerns about racism.{{Cite news|url=https://www.guernicamag.com/sara-ahmed-the-personal-is-institutional/|title=Sara Ahmed: Notes from a Feminist Killjoy|date=2017-07-17|work=Guernica|access-date=2018-09-17|language=en-US}} Lorde's poems often draw attention to the universalising tendencies of some white feminisms, so in a poem about a mythical woman, [https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems/42583/a-woman-speaks 'A Woman Speaks,'] only at the end does Lorde draw attention to the problematic universal, white woman, adding
I am woman and not white.{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poems/42583/a-woman-speaks|title=A Woman Speaks by Audre Lorde|date=2018-09-17|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-17}}
Lorde went on to be an effective and challenging teacher of other women poets, such as [[Donna Masini]]. === Feminist Anthologies in North America in the 1970s and 80s === In the 1970s and 80s, feminist poetry evolved alongside the feminist movement, becoming a useful tool for activist groups organised around [[radical feminism]], [[socialist feminism]], and [[lesbian feminism]]. Poetry readings became spaces for feminists to come together in cities and in rural communities, and talk about sexuality, women's roles, and the possibilities beyond heteronormative life. Figures like [[Judy Grahn]] were figureheads for the women's movement, providing electrifying readings that enlivened and inspired audiences. Often the poems were political, and sometimes the writers tried to use language that "ordinary women" could read and understand. Countering tokenism was also an important aspect of the feminist poetry project.{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/podcasts/143653/shattering-the-blue-velvet-chair|title=A Change of World, Episode 3: Shattering the Blue Velvet Chair - Poetry Off the Shelf|date=2018-09-26|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-26}} [[Carolyn Forché]] describes the "blue velvet chair" effect, inspired by group portraits of canonical poets, in which one - but only one - woman writer was allowed to join the men, often sat in a Victorian blue velvet chair. As poetry took on a new significance for the feminist movement, so a number of new poetry anthologies were published which emphasised women's voices and experiences.{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/907585915|title=The Oxford handbook of Canadian literature|last=|first=|publisher=|others=Sugars, Cynthia Conchita, 1963-|year=|isbn=9780199941865|location=New York, NY|pages=853|oclc=907585915}} Anthologies played an important role generally in opening up the political consciousness of poetry, an important example being [[Raymond Souster]]'s volume, ''New Wave Canada: The Explosion in Canadian Poetry'' (1966).[[Louis Dudek]] and Michael Gnarowski describe the anthology's embracing of counterculture, including new ideas about sexuality and the role of women. Other anthologies began to focus specifically on women's writing, such as: *''[[Sisterhood Is Powerful|Sisterhood is Powerful]]'' (1970) edited by [[Robin Morgan]]; *''[http://msmagazine.com/blog/2018/05/15/no-masks-celebrating-landmark-anthology-womens-poetry-45-years-later/ No More Masks!]'' (1971) edited by [[Florence Howe]] and [[Ellen Bass]]; *''[https://www.pacificaradioarchives.org/recording/bc1738 The World Split Open]'' (1972) edited by [[Louise Bernikow]]; *''Psyche'' (1973) edited by Barbara Segnitz and Carol Rainey; *''New Poets, Women'' (1976) edited by Terry Wetherby; *''Contemporary Women Poets'' (1977) edited by Jennifer McDowell and Milton Leventhal; *''Open to Sun'' (1979) edited by Nora Jacquez Wieser; *''[[Lesbian Poetry: An Anthology|Lesbian Poetry]]'' (1982) edited by Elly Bulkin and [[Joan Larkin]]; *''Daughters of the Sun, Women of the Moon: Poetry by Black Canadian Women'' (1990) edited by Ann Wallace. Other anthologies created new canons of women's writing from the past, such as ''Black sister: poetry by black American women, 1746-1980'' (1981) edited by Erlene Stetson; or ''Writing Red: An Anthology of American Women Writers, 1930-1940'' (1987) edited by Paula Rabinowitz and Charlotte Nekola. Such anthologies "established solid ground for the communication and circulation of feminist ideas" in the American and Canadian Academies. Conferences also provided important spaces for feminists to share and discuss ideas about the possibilities of poetry: for example a key moment for Canadian feminist poetry was the "Women and words / Les femmes et les motes" conference in 1983.{{Cite journal|last=Beverley|first=Andrea|date=2017|title='Women and Words'|url=https://champlainsociety.utpjournals.press/findings-trouvailles/2017/11/women-and-words-1983-visual-traces|journal=The Champlain Society - Findings|volume=|pages=|via=}} The Vancouver convention brought together women writers, publishers, and booksellers to discuss the issues of the Canadian literary world, including gender inequity. === Modern Feminist Poetry in North America === One change in the writing of women poets after the 1960s and 1970s was the possibility of writing about women's lives and experiences. To give authority to women's voices, writers like [[Honor Moore]] and [[Judy Grahn|Judy Graun]] held workshops specifically for women in order to overcome women's inner critics exacerbated by sexism. These networks of mentorship sprang up in feminist communities, and in universities. The work at this time was focussing on "images of women," and this often meant broadening representations.{{Cite journal|last=Juhasz|first=Suzanne|date=1977|title=The critic as feminist: Reflections on women's poetry, feminism, and the art of criticism|url=https://www.tandfonline.com/action/captchaChallenge?redirectUri=%2Fdoi%2Fabs%2F10.1080%2F00497878.1977.9978438|journal=Women's Studies|language=en|volume=5|issue=2|pages=113–127|doi=10.1080/00497878.1977.9978438|issn=0049-7878|via=}} This methodology eventually began to be criticised, however, because it failed to recognise the complications of violence embedded in the very structure of language.{{Cite journal|last=Sojka|first=Eugenia|date=2001|title=Canadian Feminist Writing and American Poetry|url=https://docs.lib.purdue.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1128&context=clcweb|journal=CLCWeb: Comparative Literature and Culture|volume=3.2|pages=|via=}} Writers influenced by the [[avant-garde]] and by [[Language poets|L=A=N=G=U=A=G=E poetry]] sought to challenge the idea of language's neutrality. US feminist language poets like [[Lyn Hejinian|Lynn Hejinian]] or [[Susan Howe]], or Canadian writers like [[Daphne Marlatt]] looked back to the legacy of experimentalist modernists like [[Gertrude Stein]], or [[Mina Loy]], and also to diverse sources of inspiration like [[Denise Levertov]], [[Marguerite Duras]], [[Virginia Woolf]], [[Nicole Brossard]], [[Phyllis Webb]], [[Louky Bersianik]], and [[Julia Kristeva]]. They also reframed the language poetics from male mentors like [[Charles Olson]], [[Robert Creeley]], [[Gary Snyder]], or [[Allen Ginsberg]]. Poets also sought to intervene in spheres traditionally dominated by men. Take for example [[Eileen Myles]]' intervention into politics in her 1992 "Write-in Campaign for President."{{Cite web|url=http://www.eileenmyles.net/howto.htm|title=1992 Write-in Campaign for President:  Eileen Myles|website=www.eileenmyles.net|access-date=2018-09-26}} By the time of the 1990s, and the rise of [[intersectionality]] as a key feminist term, many feminist poets resisted the term "woman poet," because it suggested "too confining a collective identity." They also sought to undermine "the assumption that has sometimes structured feminist political organizing and even feminist literary publishing and criticism—that gender can be separated from race, ethnicity, class, and sexuality, and that white middleclass women first and foremost have the tools and the knowhow for the enterprise of analyzing gendered experience and literary production." Present day feminist poetry in North America holds space for a great variety of poets tackling identity, sexuality, and gender issues. Key writings in the recent past include [[Claudia Rankine]]'s careful skewering of race related [[microaggression]]s in ''Citizen,''{{Cite news|url=https://www.nybooks.com/articles/2015/04/23/claudia-rankine-new-way-writing-about-race/|title='A New Way of Writing About Race'|last=Laird|first=Nick|work=The New York Review of Books|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-US}} Dorothea Laskey's "ferocious confession" in Rome for example,{{Cite news|url=http://feministing.com/2014/07/31/feministing-readz-dorothea-laskys-rome/|title=Feministing Readz: Dorothea Lasky's Rome|work=Feministing|access-date=2018-09-26|language=en-US}} and Bhanu Kapil's challenge the violent inherent in structures of language and institutions.{{Cite web|url=http://www.metamute.org/editorial/articles/laying-down-banlieue|title=L(a)ying Down in the Banlieue {{!}} Mute|website=www.metamute.org|language=en|access-date=2018-09-26}} == Feminist Poetry in Western Europe == [[File:Elizabeth Barrett Browning - Project Gutenberg eText 16786.jpg|thumb|Elizabeth Barrett Browning]] === Feminist Writing after Mary Wollstonecraft === Eighteenth century advocate for women's rights [[Mary Wollstonecraft|Mary Wollstonecraf]]t (1797-1851), put great emphasis on the power of the poetic imagination as a liberator tool, and many nineteenth century British women writers were inspired by Wollstonecraft to use poetry to enter public debates about gender roles, poverty, and slavery.{{Cite journal|last=Wollstonecraft|first=Mary|date=1797|title="On Poetry and Our Relish for the Beauties of Nature"|url=|journal=Monthly Magazine|volume=April|pages=279–82|via=}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/mary-wollstonecraft-shelley|title=Mary Wollstonecraft Shelley|date=2018-09-17|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-17}} The verse-novel ''[[Aurora Leigh]]'' (1856) by [[Elizabeth Barrett Browning]] (1806-1861) is one such feminist work, which challenged a prevailing attitude that women's lives were incompatible with writing poetry.{{Cite web|url=https://www.poetryfoundation.org/poets/elizabeth-barrett-browning|title=Elizabeth Barrett Browning|date=2018-09-17|website=Poetry Foundation|language=en-us|others=Poetry Foundation|access-date=2018-09-17}} ''Aurora Leigh'' had a very public impact, for example influencing the views of American social reformer [[Susan B. Anthony]] regarding the traditional roles of women, especially in relation to the tension between marriage and women's individuality.{{Cite book|title=Susan B. Anthony Rebel, Crusader, Humanitarian.|last=Lutz|first=Alma|publisher=Beacon Press|year=1959|isbn=|location=Boston|pages=}} === Late Nineteenth Century Feminist Poets in Britain === Often cited as an early feminist poet, [[Amy Levy]] (1861-1889) is described by writer [[Elaine Feinstein]] as the first modern Jewish woman poet.{{Cite book|title=Amy Levy : critical essays|last=Valman|first=Nadia|publisher=Ohio University Press|year=2010|isbn=9780821443071|location=Athens|pages=2}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.cambridge.org/core/books/jewess-in-nineteenthcentury-british-literary-culture/A059306B33CC165DA9E8AC54E5816E4C|title=The Jewess in Nineteenth-Century British Literary Culture|last=Valman|first=Nadia|date=2007|publisher=Cambridge University Press|year=|isbn=9780511484964|location=Cambridge|pages=119|language=en|doi=10.1017/CBO9780511484964}}{{Cite web|url=https://www.poets.org/poetsorg/poet/amy-levy|title=Amy Levy|last=Levy|first=Amy|date=2013-09-30|website=Amy Levy|language=en|access-date=2018-09-17}} At the age of 13, Levy published her first poem in the feminist journal, the ''Pelican'', and she grew to maturity surrounded by writers and social reformers on the London scene of the era, such as [[Eleanor Marx]] and [[Olive Schreiner|Olive Schreiber]]. Though nothing is known for sure about Levy's sexual relationships, she is often thought of as a lesbian poet, though some critics have challenged affixing a sexual category to Levy.{{Cite book|title=Women’s Poetry, Late Romantic to Late Victorian: Gender and Genre, 1830–1900|last=Blain|first=Virginia|publisher=Macmillan|year=1999|isbn=|location=London|pages=138}} Levy's poems, however, are an early example of poetry that challenges [[Heteronormativity|heteronormative]] roles.{{Cite web|url=https://www.senatehouselibrary.ac.uk/blog/amy-levy-1861-1889-'minor-poet'|title=Amy Levy (1861-1889): a ‘Minor Poet’|last=|first=|date=|website=Senate House Library, University of London|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/953030317|title=Odd women? : spinsters, lesbians and widows in British women's fiction, 1850s-1930s|last=Emma,|first=Liggins,|publisher=|year=|isbn=9781526111654|location=Manchester|pages=4|oclc=953030317}} === Twentieth Century Feminist Poets in Britain === Levy is often thought of as prefiguring or representing an early version of the New Woman, a stereotypical image of an independent woman who often worked rather than relying on her menfolk, and was associated with [[Gender bender|gender bending]] and deviance.{{Cite journal|last=Mitchell|first=Dolores|date=1991|title=The "New Woman" as Prometheus: Women Artists Depict Women Smoking|url=http://www.jstor.org/stable/1358183|journal=Woman's Art Journal|volume=12|issue=1|pages=3–9|doi=10.2307/1358183}}{{Cite web|url=http://eprints.kingston.ac.uk/20661/|title=Amy Levy: her life, her poetry and the era of the new woman|last=Christine|first=Pullen,|date=2000|website=eprints.kingston.ac.uk|access-date=2018-09-17}} Historically, the end of the nineteenth and beginning of the twentieth century was an era of surplus women, who had to work to survive: by 1911, 77 per cent of women workers in the UK were single.{{Cite journal|last=Long|first=V.|last2=Marland|first2=H.|date=2009-01-01|title=From Danger and Motherhood to Health and Beauty: Health Advice for the Factory Girl in Early Twentieth-Century Britain|url=https://academic.oup.com/tcbh/article/20/4/454/1690021|journal=Twentieth Century British History|language=en|volume=20|issue=4|pages=454–481|doi=10.1093/tcbh/hwp027|issn=0955-2359}} Alongside the struggle of [[suffragette]]s campaigning for votes for women, many British feminist poets sought to emulate the example of Victorian women writers, often expressing their radical political beliefs through poetry.{{Cite web|url=https://britlitsurvey2.wordpress.com/2013/11/08/mary-wollstonecraft-influence-beyond-the-grave/|title=Mary Wollstonecraft: Influence Beyond the Grave|last=|first=|date=|website=British Literature 1700-1900, A Course Blog|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Often the writers were not professional poets, but wrote out of necessity, including satirical portraits of politicians, or writings from prison, as in ''Holloway Jingles'', a collection of writing from imprisoned women collated by the Glasgow Branch of the [[Women's Social and Political Union]].{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/54206569|title=Literature of the women's suffrage campaign in England|last=|first=|date=2004|publisher=Broadview Press|others=Nelson, Carolyn Christensen.|year=|isbn=1551115115|location=Peterborough, Ont.|pages=153|oclc=54206569}} === British Feminist Poets and Modernism === In the inter-war years, British women poets associated with modernism began to find themselves public figures, though their feminist ideas sometimes came into conflict with the literary establishment which remained a kind of "exclusive male club."{{Cite book|title=Women, Modernism and British Poetry, 1910–1939: Resisting Femininity|last=Dowson|first=Jane|publisher=Ash gate|year=2002|isbn=9780754604631|location=Burlington, VT|pages=}} Often these writers are difficult to categorize in relation to literary groups traditionally used, like the [[avant-garde]] or [[Modernism|modernists]]. This was also a period when American women poets living in Britain made an important contribution to the writing of the day: writers like [[H.D.]], [[Mina Loy]], and [[Amy Lowell]] all combined radical poetic content with experimentation of form, allowing them to explore feminist polemic and non-heteronormative sexualities in innovative new modes. Other British feminist poets of the time like [[Anna Wickham]], [[Charlotte Mew]], and [[Sylvia Townsend Warner]], receive less critical attention, but also sought to challenge and reevaluate tropes of femininity. === Post 1960s Feminist Poetry in Britain === During the 1960s, the Women's Liberation Movement in the UK had a great influence on the literary world.{{Cite web|url=https://www.bl.uk/sisterhood/articles/feminist-literature|title=Feminist literature|last=Sisterhood and After Research Team|first=|date=|website=The British Library|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}} Feminist publishers, [[Virago Press|Virago]] (founded in 1973), [[Onlywomen Press|Onlywomen]] (1974), The Women's Press (1978), and Sheba (1980), were established, alongside magazines like [https://www.bl.uk/spare-rib Spare Rib]. Like their counterparts in the US, British feminist editors in the 1970s and 80s created landmark anthologies of women's poetry, which foregrounded the variety and strength of women's writing. These included Lilian Mohin's ''One Foot on the Mountain'' (1979), [[Jeni Couzyn]]'s ''The Bloodaxe Book of Contemporary Women Poets'' (1985), Moira Ferguson's ''First Feminists: British Women Writers 1578-1799'' (1985), Kate Armstrong's ''Fresh Oceans'' (1989), Jude Brigley's ''Exchanges'' (1990), and Catherine Kerrigan's ''An Anthology of Scottish Women Poets'' (1991). {{Notability|Organizations|date=December 2008}} '''Fugitive Projects''' is a [[Non-profit organization|non-profit]] curatorial arts organization, arts collective, and beehive operating since 1999 out of [[Nashville, Tennessee]].
From 1999- 2005 Fugitive Projects called itself the '''Fugitive Art Center''' bringing national and international artists to Nashville to exhibit in their warehouse gallery space. In both configurations they served as an artist advocacy, curatorial resource and databank. Since restructuring they have focused more on ephemeral exhibitions and involvement with exhibitions traveling to the [[IMAFY]] in [[Egypt]]; [[Banff, Alberta|Banff]], [[Canada]] for [[The Interactive Screen Conference]]; [[Ireland]]'s [[Dublin Electronic Arts Festival]]; [[Basel, Switzerland]] and to venues across the U.S. Artists with video works in this touring program included [[Hernan Bas]], [[Charles De Meaux]], [[e*rock]], [[Haus am Gern]], [[Jenna Gribbon]], [[Muda Matthis / Sus Zwick]], [[Casey Reas]], [[Scott Reeder (artist)|Scott Reeder]], [[Magda Tothova]], [[Moliu Zhang]], [[Eliane Rutishauser]], [[Melody Owen]], [[Charles Huntley Nelson]], [[Kristin Lucas]], Matt Freedman, [[Bert Rodriguez]], [[Dominic DeJoseph]], [[Nicolas Lobo]], [[Karina Nimmerfall]], [[Jeff Luckey]], and [[Joseph Burwell]] among others.
David Maddox in the ''[[Nashville Scene]]'' said in 2004 "the Fugitive (Art Center) has become an essential part of Nashville's art scene...The Fugitive can point to a steady series of good shows, but that's only part of the group's significance to Nashville. Its 12-person board provides a cross-section of the city's art scene."
Susan Knowles, in [[Art Papers]], refers to The Fugitive Art Center as "unbridled energy", "a lightning rod for artists" and "the edge of visual dialogue in Nashville- and Tennessee."

[[File:El hombre amigable.jpg|thumb|Greetingman statue, [[Buceo]] neighbourhood, [[Montevideo, Uruguay]].]] '''''Greetingman''''' ({{lang-ko|그리팅맨}}) is a modern sculpture project in South Korea.
Its main artist is [[Yoo Young-ho]] (South Korean sculptor). The concept provides a man, 6 m high, [[bowing]] in a typically Asian greeting gesture. The blue color means lack of prejudice.
In October 2012, a statue was unveiled in the neighbourhood of [[Buceo]], [[Montevideo]], [[Uruguay]],<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.elpais.com.uy/121020/pespec-670696/espectaculos/Escultura-coreana-en-rambla-de-Buceo/ |title=Korean sculpture on the Montevidean seashore|date=2012-10-20|publisher=EL PAIS}} {{es icon}}</ref> as part of a planned world series in multiple locations.<ref>[http://www.greetingman.com/future.html Future of Greetingman]</ref><ref>[http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_entertainment/486476.html One thousand greetings]''The Hankyoreh''. 8 July 2011</ref>
Another statue was unveiled in October 2013 in [[South Korea]], near the [[Korean Demilitarized Zone]], in Haean, [[Yanggu County, Gangwon]].<ref>{{cite web |url=http://english.hani.co.kr/arti/english_edition/e_national/608543.html |title=Greeting Man statue coming to Korean War battleground |publisher=The Hankyoreh |date=25 October 2013}}</ref>
A third statue was unveiled in January 2016 in [[Panama City, Panama]], the second to be unveiled in Latin America.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://laestrella.com.pa/estilo/cultura/develan-escultura-degreetingman-costa-este/23917137/foto/205961 |title=Develan escultura de "Greetingman" en la ciudad de Panamá |publisher=La Estrella de Panamá |date=20 January 2016}}</ref>

[[File:Hinman collator.jpg|thumb|A Hinman collator owned by the [[Folger Shakespeare Library]]]] The '''Hinman collator''', an early [[optical collator]], was an [[opto-mechanical]] device for comparing pairs of documents for differences in the text. Documents that appeared similar were said to “collate”. The collator resulted in rapid advances in the study of [[Literature|literary]] works.
Invented by [[Charlton Hinman]] in the late 1940s, the device used [[light bulb|lights]] and [[mirror]]s to superimpose images of the two documents so that differences in text alignment or wording stood out. This resulted in huge improvements in speed and efficiency compared to the traditional [[Cross-reference|cross-referencing]] of texts by eye.
The idea built on earlier work such as [[Carl Pulfrich|Carl Pulfrich's]] [[blink comparator]] used to help identify the former planet [[Pluto]], and Hinman's work analysing aerial photographs during [[World War II]].
Hinman used his device to compare the many slightly different impressions of the [[First Folio]] of [[William Shakespeare]]'s works. The [[printing]] and [[bookbinding]] processes used in the time of Shakespeare often resulted in variations in the pages bound into the final books, and the collator enabled Hinman to describe the exact order in which the Folios had been composited and printed. He used the collator to compare 55 different copies of the First Folio held by the [[Folger Shakespeare Library]], and subsequently wrote about his findings in ''Printing and Proof-reading of the First Folio of Shakespeare'' in 1963.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://collation.folger.edu/2011/08/welcome-to-the-collation/ |title=Welcome to The Collation |last1=Werner |first1=Sarah |date=August 18, 2011 |website=The Collation |publisher=[[Folger Shakespeare Library]] |access-date=July 16, 2015}}</ref>
In the wake of Hinman's success, the device was purchased by a number of universities, libraries and other institutions (allegedly including the [[CIA]]).<ref>{{cite journal |title = "The Eternal Verities Verified": Charlton Hinman and the Roots of Mechanical Collation |last = Smith |first = Steven Escar |journal = [[Studies in Bibliography]] |publisher = [[Bibliographical Society of the University of Virginia]] |issn = 0081-7600 |volume = 53 |year = 2000 |pages = 129–61 |jstor = 40372096 |via = [[JSTOR]] |registration = y |ref = harv }}</ref> As more compact types of collator were developed in the 1960s, the last Hinman was built in 1978. In his 2002 survey of mechanical collators, Steven Escar Smith estimates from scattered records that as many as 59 Hinman Collators were produced, 41 of these surviving at the time of his survey's publication. <ref>{{cite journal |title = "Armadillos of Invention": A Census of Mechanical Collators |last = Smith |first = Steven Escar |journal = [[Studies in Bibliography]] |publisher = [[Bibliographical Society of the University of Virginia]] |issn = 0081-7600 |volume = 55 |year = 2002 |pages = 133–70 |jstor = 40372237 |via = [[JSTOR]] |registration = y |ref = harv }}</ref>
The device was developed further by Randall McLeod.<ref>Zalewski, Daniel. [http://linguafranca.mirror.theinfo.org/9706/fieldnotes.html ''Through the looking glass.''] Lingua franca, June 1997.</ref>

{{Use mdy dates|date=April 2014}} {{Infobox writer | name = Hiromi Itō
伊藤 比呂美 | image = Hiromi Ito 2009-10-04.jpg | imagesize = 300px | caption = | pseudonym = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1955|9|13}} | birth_place = Tokyo, Japan | death_date = | death_place = | occupation = Poet, novelist | nationality = Japanese | period = [[Modernist literature|Modern]] | genre = Poetry | subject = | movement = | spouse = | partner = [[Harold Cohen (artist)|Harold Cohen]] | children = | relatives = | influences = | influenced = | signature = | website = }} {{nihongo|'''Hiromi Itō'''|伊藤 比呂美|Itō Hiromi|born September 13, 1955}} is one of the most prominent [[women's writing (literary category)|woman writers]] of contemporary Japan, with more than a dozen collections of [[Japanese poetry|poetry]], several works of [[prose]], numerous books of essays, and several major literary prizes to her name. She divides her time between the towns of [[Encinitas]], California and [[Kumamoto]] in southern Japan. ==Biography == ===Early career === Born in 1955 in Tokyo, Itō became well known in the 1980s for a series of dramatic collections of poetry that described [[Human sexuality|sexuality]], pregnancy, and feminine erotic desire in dramatically direct language. From her earliest work, Itō embarked on a lifelong battle against the stylized and artful language common in 20th-century [[Japanese poetry]]. Much of her poetry is narrated in extended passages of relatively [[colloquial]] text.[[Jeffrey Angles]], Translator's Introduction, ''Killing Kanoko: Selected Poems of Hiromi Itō'' (Notre Dame, IN: Action Books, 2009), p. vii–xii. Her poems so skillfully represent spoken language that they often give the illusion of being records of spoken speech. Not coincidentally, commentators have often described Itō as a "[[shaman]]ess" for her ability to channel voices onto the page.See for instance, Kido Shuri's comments in ''Sengo meishi sen II,'' (Tokyo: Shichōsha, 2001), p. 230. ===Women's issues=== In 1982, Itō's book {{nihongo|''Unripe Plums''|青梅|Aoume}},'appeared in the series "The Present State of Women's Poetry," which was published by the Japanese publisher [[Shichōsha]] and also featured a number of rising young female poets, including [[Toshiko Hirata]], [[Yōko Isaka]], and [[Kōko Shiraishi]]. In the mid-1980s, Itō's writing gravitated to issues of the feminine body, sexuality, and motherhood, making her the most prominent voice of what came to be known as the "women's poetry boom." The two collections {{nihongo|''On Territory 2''|テリトリー論1|Teritorī ron 2}}, published in 1985, and {{nihongo|''On Territory 1''|テリトリー論2|Teritorī ron 1}}, published in 1987, describe her feelings after giving birth to her first daughter, [[Kanoko Nishi]]. These poems probe the meaning of the mother-child relationship and the demands that [[motherhood]] places on the mother's identity and sexuality.[[Jeffrey Angles]], Translator's Introduction, ''Killing Kanoko: Selected Poems of Hiromi Itō'' (Notre Dame, IN: Action Books, 2009), p. vii–xii. For instance, in the often anthologized poem {{nihongo|"Killing Kanoko"|カノコ殺し|Kanoko-goroshi}}, she describes the feelings of a young mother experiencing [[postpartum depression]] and anger at her newborn, even though the world is congratulating her on becoming a mother.Translated in Hiromi Itō, ''Killing Kanoko: Selected Poetry of Hiromi Itō'' (Notre Dame, IN: Action Books, 2009), pp. 33–39. Her eagerness to explore women's issues has led some to think of her as a [[feminist]] writer, although this is a term that Itō has not always embraced in building her public persona.Joanne Quimby, 'How to Write "Women's Poetry" without Being a "Woman Poet": Public Persona in Itō Hiromi's Early Poetry,' ''U.S.-Japan Women's Journal,'' vol. 32 (2007): 7–16. Throughout her career, however, Itō has embraced the metaphor of the poet as a [[shaman]]ess. In 1991, she collaborated with the prominent feminist scholar [[Chizuko Ueno]] from [[Tokyo University]] on a collection of essays and poetry called {{nihongo|''The Shamaness and Her Interpreter''|のろとさにわと|Noro to saniwa to}}, which the two likened to the collaboration between an [[Okinawa]]n shamaness and the figure who makes sense of her utterances for the outside world. A few years later in 1993, Itō explicitly played out the metaphor of poet as shamaness in her long narrative poem {{nihongo|'I Am Anjuhimeko'|わたしはあんじゅひめ子である|Watashi wa Anjuhimeko de aru}}, in which she takes a story recorded from a shamaness in [[Tsugaru Peninsula|Tsugaru]] in the early 20th century and refashions it into a dramatic new myth of [[healing]] from [[sexual abuse]] and self-discovery.[[Jeffrey Angles]], "Reclaiming the Unwritten: The Work of Memory in Itō Hiromi's ''Watashi wa Anjuhimeko de aru (I Am Anjuhimeko),''" ''U.S.-Japan Women's Journal,'' vol. 32 (2007): 51–75. For a translation, see Hiromi Itō, ''Killing Kanoko: Selected Poetry of Hiromi Itō,'' (Notre Dame, IN: 2009), pp. 99–115. ===Relocation to the US=== Since at least the 1980s, Itō had been fascinated with Native American poetry, which she first read in Japanese translations. In 1990, she met the American poet [[Jerome Rothenberg]] when he visited Japan. Rothenberg had been a major force in re-examining Native American poetry in the movement known as "[[ethnopoetics]]," and he encouraged Itō to come to America. She had recently separated from her husband, the literature scholar [[Masahiko Nishi]], and at Rothenberg's invitation, she started making regular, extended trips to America with her children, before eventually settling in 1997 in [[Encinitas]], California with her new partner, the British artist [[Harold Cohen (artist)|Harold Cohen]]. The change of setting led to several significant changes in her writing, in terms of both [[genre]] and subject matter. She began writing novellas, both because she was tired of poetry and because she felt [[prose]] was better suited to exploring her new experiences as an immigrant. Several of her novellas from this time describe the difficulties of immigration and the experience of being a transplant in a new environment.Kyōko Ōmori, "'Finding Our Own English:' Migrancy, Identity, and Language(s) in Itō Hiromi's Recent Prose," ''U.S.-Japan Women's Journal,'' vol. 32 (2007): 92–114. ===Since 2000=== Itō returned to poetry, publishing several long, [[fantasy|fantastic]] narrative works that blur the lines between prose and poetry. These include {{nihongo|''Wild Grass on a Riverbank''|河原荒草|Kawara arekusa}}, published in 2005, the narrative {{nihongo|''Coyote Song''|コヨーテ・ソング|Koyōte songu}}, published in 2007, and {{nihongo|''The Thorn-Puller: New Tales of the Sugamo Jizō''|とげ抜き 新巣鴨地蔵縁起|Toge-nuki: Shin Sugamo Jizō engi}}, published in 2007. In these works, Itō writes about the experiences of modern people, often [[immigrant|migrants]] or [[International|transnational]]s, but does so in a way that has an almost [[mythology|mythological]] grandeur and frequently veers into the [[surrealism|surreal]]. One of Itō's bestsellers was her book of essays {{nihongo|''The Heart Sutra Explained''|読み解き般若心経|Yomitoki Hannnya shingyō}}, published in 2010. This book consists of a series of personal essays about her involvement with the [[Buddhism|Buddhist]] classic, the [[Heart Sutra]], and other [[Buddhist texts]]. While relating the texts to her own life, she describes her understanding of the text and provides her own modern Japanese translation from the [[classical Chinese]]. Itō's interest in [[Buddhism]] and [[Buddhist texts]] in particular had been visible earlier in her career, for instance, in the 1993 poem {{nihongo|'I Am Anjuhimeko'|わたしはあんじゅひめ子である|Watashi wa Anjuhimeko de aru}}, which incorporates elements of folk Buddhist narrative, and the 2004 book {{nihongo|''Strange Tales from Japan''|日本ノ霊異ナ話|Nihon no fushigi na hanashi}}, which retells several of the stories in the [[Heian period|Heian-period]] Buddhist classic [[Nihon Ryōiki]] by the [[Buddhist monk|monk]] [[Kyōkai]]. In 2012, Itō published {{nihongo|''Reading the ''Lamentations of Divergences'' Falteringly Out Loud''|たどたどしく声に出して読む歎異抄|Tadotadoshiku koe ni dashite yomu tannishō}}, a book of personal essays and contemporary Japanese translations of [[Letter (message)|correspondence]] between the Japanese Buddhist monk [[Shinran]] and his mother. A common theme in these books, especially ''The Heart Sutra Explained'', ''Reading the ''Lamentations of Divergences'' Falteringly Out Loud'', and the 2014 book {{nihongo|''A Father's Life''|父の生きる|Chichi no ikiru}} about the slow decline and death of Itō's father, is the question of how life changes as one grows older and faces death. (This is a major issue in Japan due to the [[demographics|demographic]] imbalances brought about Japan's [[Japan demographics|declining birth rate and rise in numbers of senior citizens]]). As a means to understand and cope with this process, Itō frequently turns to [[Buddhist texts]] for inspiration. In addition to these works of poetry and prose, Itō has published numerous books of essays, [[manga]] criticism, and translations of [[American literature]] for young Japanese readers. Among the books she has translated into Japanese are ''[[The Cat in the Hat]]'' and ''[[Oh, the Places You'll Go!]]'' by [[Dr. Seuss]], as well as the two books ''[[Out of the Dust]]'' and ''[[Witness (Karen Hesse novel)|Witness]]'' by [[Karen Hesse]].[[Jeffrey Angles]], "Dr. Seuss Goes to Japan: Ideology and the Translation of an American Icon," ''Japan Forum'' 26.2 (May 2014): 177-183. In addition to her modern Japanese translations of the [[Buddhist texts]] mentioned above, she has also written a modern Japanese translation of a short story by [[Ichiyō Higuchi]]. Itō divides her time between her home in [[Encinitas]], [[California]] and [[Kumamoto]] in southern Japan. In the latter, she has been the organizing force between a group of local writers and artists known as the {{nihongo|"Kumamoto Band"|熊本文学隊|Kumamoto bungakutai}}. Itō's work is featured prominently in the [[Kumamoto Modern Literature Museum]]. ==Awards== * 1978: [[Gendai Shi Techo Prize]] for the poetry collection {{nihongo|''Sky of Plants''|草木の空|Sōmoku no sora}} * 1993: Nominated for [[Mishima Yukio Prize]] for {{nihongo|''Art of Family''|家族アート|Kazoku āto}} * 1998: Nominated for [[Akutagawa Prize]] for the novella {{nihongo|''House Plant''|ハウス・プラント|Hausu puranto}} * 1999: Nominated for [[Akutagawa Prize]] for the novella {{nihongo|''Ranīnya''|ラニーニャ|La Niña}} * 1999: [[Noma Literary Prize]] for New Writers for the novella {{nihongo|''Ranīnya''|ラニーニャ|La Niña}} * 2006: [[Takami Jun Prize]] for the book {{nihongo|''Wild Grass on a Riverbank''|河原荒草|Kawara arekusa}} * 2007: [[Hagiwara Sakutarō Prize]] for the novel {{nihongo|''The Thorn-Puller: New Tales of the Sugamo Jizō''|とげ抜き 新巣鴨地蔵縁起|Toge-nuki: Shin Sugamo Jizō engi}} * 2008: [[Izumi Shikibu Prize]] for the novel {{nihongo|''The Thorn-Puller: New Tales of the Sugamo Jizō''|とげ抜き 新巣鴨地蔵縁起|Toge-nuki: Shin Sugamo Jizō engi}} ==See also== *[[Japanese literature]] *[[Japanese poetry]] *[[Feminism]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==Bibliography== '''Translations into English''' * Itō, Hiromi (2009), ''Killing Kanoko: Selected Poems of Hiromi Itō'', translated by [[Jeffrey Angles]].
